affirmation: Endometriosis is characterized by a shift from Th1 to Th2/Th17 immune dominance

references.justification: Comprehensive review demonstrating that Th17 cells are highly expressed in peritoneal fluid of endometriosis patients and contribute to disease development through IL-17a secretion and inflammation promotion
Research article showing endometriosis is associated with immune dysfunction and imbalance in Th1/Th2 cell responses, leading to abnormal cytokine secretion and inflammation
Recent study analyzing the correlation between immune cells and endometriosis, providing evidence for altered immune cell balance including Th2/Th17 dominance

counter_affirmation: Endometriosis is not characterized by a shift from Th1 to Th2/Th17 immune dominance

counter_references.justification: Study demonstrating that Th1 response patterns are specifically related to deep infiltrating endometriosis, with higher TNF-alpha and IL-2 concentrations, contradicting universal Th2/Th17 dominance
Research showing that immune responses in endometriosis are heterogeneous and inconsistent, indicating that simple Th1→Th2/Th17 shift models may not accurately represent the complex immune landscape
Review highlighting the multifaceted nature of immune responses in endometriosis with findings that are often inconsistent, challenging the concept of a uniform immune shift across all patients

affirmation: Foxp3-positive regulatory T cells are functionally impaired in endometriosis

references.justification: Study demonstrating that the proportion of activated Tregs is significantly decreased in endometrioma and endometrium of women with endometriosis, leading to exacerbated local inflammation and angiogenesis
Research showing that the percentage of activated Treg cells is significantly lower in endometrium and endometriosis tissue samples compared to controls, indicating functional impairment
Study analyzing CD4+CD25+FOXP3+ regulatory T cells in peripheral blood and peritoneal fluid, revealing altered Treg distribution and function contributing to endometriosis immunopathogenesis

counter_affirmation: Foxp3-positive regulatory T cells are not functionally impaired in endometriosis

counter_references.justification: Study demonstrating that CD4+Foxp3+ regulatory T cells are significantly increased in peritoneal fluid of endometriosis patients with enhanced function, contributing to endometriotic immunotolerance and facilitating lesion progression

Research showing that endometriotic peritoneal fluid actively stimulates recruitment of CD4+CD25highFOXP3+ Treg cells, indicating functional and responsive regulatory mechanisms rather than impairment

Review highlighting that Tregs maintain their immunosuppressive function in endometriosis and actively contribute to disease development by suppressing immune responses and promoting ectopic tissue establishment

affirmation: NK cell cytotoxicity is reduced in endometriosis patients

references.justification: Classic study demonstrating that women with endometriosis show a defect in natural killer activity resulting in decreased cytotoxicity to autologous endometrium
Comprehensive review establishing NK cells as key players in endometriosis pathogenesis, with documented reduction in cytotoxic activity correlating with disease severity
Research showing decreased peritoneal natural killer cytotoxicity specifically in women with stage III-IV endometriosis, demonstrating severity-dependent NK dysfunction

counter_affirmation: NK cell cytotoxicity is not reduced in endometriosis patients

counter_references.justification: Study finding no difference in the proportion of NK cells in peripheral blood between women with and without endometriosis, indicating that NK cell dysfunction may be functional rather than quantitative
Research demonstrating that IL-2 stimulation of PBMCs from endometriosis patients enhances CD107a expression and cytotoxic activity, showing preserved functional capacity when properly activated
Study showing that IL-2-activated NK cells from endometriosis patients can effectively distinguish between normal and malignant endometrial cells, indicating intact cytotoxic recognition mechanisms

affirmation: IL-10 anti-inflammatory signaling is disrupted in endometriosis

references.justification: Study demonstrating dysregulation of IL-1/IL-1-R system linked to immunological dysfunction in endometriosis, with downregulated IL-1 receptor type 1 expression affecting anti-inflammatory response pathways
Review examining anti-inflammatory cytokines in endometriosis, documenting disrupted anti-inflammatory signaling mechanisms and inadequate immune regulation despite cytokine presence
Research showing higher IL-10 levels in peritoneal fluid of endometriosis patients, paradoxically associated with continued inflammation, indicating disrupted IL-10 signaling effectiveness

counter_affirmation: IL-10 anti-inflammatory signaling is not disrupted in endometriosis

counter_references.justification: Study demonstrating that IL-27 triggers functional IL-10 production in Th17 cells via intact c-Maf/RORγt/Blimp-1 signaling pathways, indicating preserved IL-10 signaling mechanisms that actively promote endometriosis progression

Research showing elevated IL-10 levels in peritoneal fluid of endometriosis patients, demonstrating that IL-10 is being produced and released normally, indicating functional rather than disrupted signaling
Study on IL-10 expression showing that IL-10 effectively contributes to immunosuppression maintenance in ectopic foci, indicating intact and functional anti-inflammatory signaling pathways

affirmation: Transcription factors T-bet, GATA3, and RORγt show altered balance in endometriosis

references.justification: Study demonstrating modulation of T-bet and GATA-3 transcription factor expression in human endometrial stromal cells by sex steroid hormones, indicating altered transcriptional regulation in endometriosis
Research showing increased T-helper 2 and T-regulatory cell populations in endometriosis patients, indicating altered balance of GATA3 and Foxp3 transcription factor-regulated cell types
Study documenting upregulated IL-17 expression in endometriotic lesions and increased Th17 cell activity, indicating altered RORγt transcription factor activity and Th17 differentiation balance

counter_affirmation: Transcription factors T-bet, GATA3, and RORγt do not show altered balance in endometriosis

counter_references.justification: Study demonstrating normal cyclic regulation of T-bet and GATA-3 in human endometrium, indicating that observed expression changes represent normal physiological variation rather than pathological alteration

Research showing that transcription factor expression in endometrium correlates significantly with progesterone serum levels and varies with menstrual cycle phases, suggesting hormonal influence rather than intrinsic transcriptional dysfunction

Meta-analysis revealing that immune profile differences in endometriosis are independent of hormonal milieu, suggesting that transcription factor changes may be secondary to other factors rather than primary transcriptional imbalance
